definitions: move or cause to move in a circular direction around an axis or point
change or cause to change direction when moving
change in nature, state, form or condition to become something different
reach or pass a particular age or time marker in life
become sour, bad, or change to an undesirable state
examples: She turned the key slowly in the lock
The wheels turned faster as the car accelerated
Turn left at the next traffic light ahead
The river turns sharply near the old bridge
The caterpillar will turn into a beautiful butterfly
His hair turned gray after years of stress
My daughter just turned five years old yesterday
The company turns fifty this year in December
The milk turned sour in the summer heat
His mood turned dark when he heard news

definitions: catch or hunt turtles for food or other purposes
turn upside down accidentally, especially of boats or vehicles
examples: They turtle along the coast during summer months
Local fishermen turtle to supplement their income annually
The canoe turtled in the rough rapids yesterday
Strong winds caused several sailboats to turtle completely

definitions: engage in a vigorous struggle or scuffle involving physical contact
struggle or compete vigorously to achieve something against opposition
examples: The two boys tussled over the basketball roughly
Security guards tussled with protesters outside the building
Companies tussle for market share in emerging economies
Politicians tussled over the controversial new policy proposal

definitions: give individual instruction or teaching to a student privately
act as a guardian or supervisor in educational settings
examples: She tutors high school students in advanced mathematics
He tutored his younger brother for the entrance exam
The professor tutors graduate students through their research
Senior students tutor freshmen during their first semester

definitions: make or cause to make a sharp, vibrating sound like a plucked string
speak with a distinctive nasal accent or regional pronunciation
examples: The guitar string twanged loudly when it broke
He twanged the rubber band across the room
She twanged her words with a Southern accent
The country singer twanged through the entire performance

definitions: make small adjustments or fine-tuning to improve something
pinch, pull or twist something sharply, typically a body part
examples: She tweaked the design to make it more appealing
Engineers tweaked the settings for optimal performance levels
He playfully tweaked his sister's nose at dinner
The nurse tweaked the IV line into position

definitions: post a message on the social media platform Twitter
make a chirping sound characteristic of small birds
examples: She tweets about politics several times every day
The company tweeted an apology for the service
Birds tweet loudly outside my window every morning
The sparrows tweeted cheerfully in the garden trees

definitions: link or combine two things as a matched pair or partnership
occur or happen at the same time as something else
examples: The city twinned with Paris for cultural exchanges
They twinned the programs to maximize educational benefits
Her promotion twinned with a significant salary increase
The celebrations twinned perfectly with the national holiday

definitions: twist strands or threads together to form string or rope
wind or wrap something around another object in spirals
examples: She twined the fibers into a strong rope
Workers twined hemp strands to make durable cord
Ivy twined around the old garden trellis beautifully
She twined her fingers through his hair lovingly

definitions: shine with a light that repeatedly becomes brighter and dimmer
shine brightly with amusement, joy or other positive emotion
examples: Stars twinkled in the clear night sky above
Christmas lights twinkled on every house and tree
Her eyes twinkled with mischief and delighted humor
His face twinkled with amusement at the joke

definitions: turn, rotate or bend something into a different shape using force
deliberately change or distort the meaning of words or facts
follow a winding or curving path through space
injure a joint or muscle by sudden wrenching movement
examples: She twisted the cap off the bottle easily
He twisted the wire into an intricate shape
Don't twist my words to suit your argument
The media twisted the facts to create controversy
The mountain road twists through the steep valley
The river twists and turns for many miles
She twisted her ankle on the uneven pavement
He twisted his knee during the soccer match

definitions: make a sudden small involuntary movement of a muscle or body part
give a sudden sharp pull or jerk to something
examples: His eye twitched nervously during the interview yesterday
The rabbit's nose twitched as it sensed danger
She twitched the curtain aside to look outside
He twitched the fishing line to attract fish

definitions: make a series of short, high-pitched sounds like birds
talk rapidly and excitedly in a nervous or trivial manner
examples: Birds twittered in the trees at dawn today
Sparrows twittered constantly outside the kitchen window yesterday
The audience twittered excitedly before the show began
She twittered nervously about nothing important at all

definitions: write something using a keyboard on a computer or typewriter
classify or categorize according to shared qualities or characteristics
examples: She types over eighty words per minute accurately
Please type your report and submit it tomorrow
Scientists type specimens according to their genetic markers
Don't type people based on superficial characteristics alone

definitions: repeatedly cast an actor in the same type of role based on appearance or previous performances
examples: Hollywood often typecasts actors after one successful role
She was typecast as a villain throughout her career
Directors shouldn't typecast performers based on their ethnicity
He struggled being typecast in romantic comedy roles only

definitions: arrange text and images into pages ready for printing using specialized equipment or software
examples: The publisher typeset the manuscript in elegant Garamond font
They typeset the entire book in just three days
Designers typeset the magazine using modern desktop publishing software
The printer typeset wedding invitations with decorative borders yesterday

definitions: act as an official who watches a game or match closely to enforce rules and resolve disputes
examples: She umpired the championship baseball game last weekend
He has umpired professional tennis matches for ten years
Will you umpire our cricket match this Saturday afternoon?
The retired player now umpires youth basketball games regularly

definitions: remove a cover or covering from something to expose it
discover something hidden, secret or previously unknown through investigation
examples: She uncovered the pot to check the boiling pasta
Workers uncovered ancient ruins beneath the modern building
Journalists uncovered corruption in the city government last year
The investigation uncovered evidence of financial fraud yesterday

definitions: offer goods or services at a lower price than a competitor
weaken, undermine or damage something's effectiveness or credibility
examples: Online retailers undercut traditional stores with lower prices
They undercut competitors by reducing their profit margins significantly
His actions undercut the team's efforts to succeed
False rumors undercut her credibility as a witness completely

definitions: estimate something to be smaller, less important or less valuable than it actually is
examples: Don't underestimate the time needed for this complex project
Many people underestimate the costs of home renovation projects
Never underestimate your opponent in a chess match
The company underestimated customer demand for the product significantly

definitions: experience or be subjected to something, typically something unpleasant or demanding
examples: She will undergo surgery next week at the hospital
The building underwent extensive renovations last year
Students undergo rigorous training before certification
The company is undergoing major restructuring this quarter

definitions: be the fundamental basis or foundation of something more complex or apparent
examples: Scientific principles underlie all modern technological advances today
Deep insecurities underlie his aggressive behavior toward others
Cultural values underlie many of our social customs
Economic factors underlie most political decisions in government

definitions: draw a line under text to mark or highlight it
emphasize or draw attention to something's importance or significance
examples: Please underline all the important dates in red
She underlined key passages in her textbook yesterday
This crisis underlines the need for better preparation
The report underlines serious problems in our system

definitions: gradually weaken or damage someone's power, authority or confidence
erode the base or foundation of something, making it unstable
examples: Constant criticism undermined her confidence over many months
Corruption undermines public trust in government institutions significantly
Water undermined the cliff face causing dangerous erosion
Termites undermined the wooden structure of the house

definitions: support or strengthen a structure from below with props or foundation
form the theoretical or philosophical basis for an argument or belief
examples: Steel beams underpin the entire building structure securely
Workers underpinned the old foundation with concrete yesterday
Scientific evidence underpins our understanding of climate change
Strong values underpin successful organizational cultures

definitions: draw a line under text or add an underscore character
emphasize or highlight the importance of something strongly
examples: Please underscore your name on the application form
The programmer underscored variable names in the code
Recent events underscore the urgency of climate action
The study underscores significant gaps in healthcare access

definitions: perceive the intended meaning or significance of words, language or behavior
be sympathetically aware of someone's feelings or situation
interpret or view something in a particular way
examples: I understand French but cannot speak it fluently
She understands complex mathematical concepts easily
I understand why you feel frustrated about this
Parents understand the challenges of raising teenagers today
I understand that you will arrive tomorrow morning
We understand the contract expires next month officially

definitions: study and learn another performer's role to be able to replace them if necessary
examples: She understudied the lead role for six months
Young actors often understudy established performers on Broadway
He understudied three different parts in the production
The soprano understudied the principal singer all season long

definitions: commit oneself to begin and complete a task or responsibility
formally promise or guarantee to do something
examples: She undertook the challenging project despite limited resources
The company undertook major renovations of all facilities
I undertake to complete the work by Friday
They undertook to pay all damages within thirty days

definitions: accept financial responsibility for or guarantee payment of something
sign and accept liability under an insurance policy
examples: The bank underwrote the entire construction loan yesterday
Investors underwrote the company's public stock offering completely
The company underwrites policies worth millions of dollars
They underwrite marine insurance for commercial shipping vessels

definitions: reverse or cancel the effects of a previous action or decision
unfasten, untie or open something that was fastened or tied
examples: You can undo your last action with this button
The court undid years of environmental protection progress
Please undo your seatbelt after the plane stops
She undid the knot with her nimble fingers

definitions: dig something up from or out of the ground
discover information or evidence that was hidden or secret
examples: Archaeologists unearthed ancient pottery at the excavation site
The dog unearthed bones buried in the backyard
Investigators unearthed evidence of widespread fraud yesterday
Researchers unearthed documents revealing the true story

definitions: open or spread out something that was folded
develop or happen gradually over time
reveal or disclose information gradually or in stages
examples: She unfolded the map on the table carefully
The bird unfolded its wings before taking flight
Events unfolded rapidly over the next few hours
The drama unfolded throughout the entire evening slowly
The detective unfolded his theory to the assembled group
The story unfolds through multiple character perspectives beautifully

definitions: bring together separate parts or groups to form a single unified whole
examples: The treaty unified the warring nations under one government
Technology helps unify global communications systems effectively
The leader unified the party after years of division
Common goals unified the diverse community members successfully

definitions: organize workers into a labor union or become organized into a union
examples: Workers voted to unionize the factory last month
The company's employees unionized to negotiate better wages
Tech workers are beginning to unionize across the industry
They successfully unionized after months of organizing efforts

definitions: come or bring together for a common purpose or to form a whole
join together in marriage or formal partnership
examples: The crisis united people from different political backgrounds
Common interests unite the members of this club
The ceremony united two prominent families through marriage
Love united them despite their different backgrounds completely

definitions: release a dog or animal from a leash or restraint
cause a strong force, emotion or phenomenon to be released suddenly
examples: He unleashed his dogs in the fenced yard
The trainer unleashed the hunting dogs at dawn
The storm unleashed its fury on the coast
Her speech unleashed a wave of protests nationwide

definitions: remove goods or cargo from a vehicle, ship or container
remove ammunition from a weapon or discharge it
sell or get rid of assets or investments quickly
examples: Workers unloaded the truck in twenty minutes yesterday
They unloaded cargo from the ship all morning
Please unload your weapon before entering the range
The soldier unloaded his rifle after the exercise
Investors unloaded their shares when prices peaked yesterday
The company unloaded unprofitable divisions last quarter

definitions: open a lock using a key, combination or other method
release or make available something's hidden potential or capabilities
examples: She unlocked the door with her electronic key
Can you unlock this cabinet for me please?
Education unlocks opportunities for personal growth and development
This discovery unlocked new possibilities in medical treatment

definitions: remove a mask or disguise from someone's face
expose the true character or nature of someone or something
examples: The hero unmasked the villain at the costume party
She unmasked herself after the masquerade ball ended
The investigation unmasked corruption at the highest levels
The journalist unmasked the fraud behind the scheme

definitions: undo twisted, knitted or woven threads or fabric
investigate and solve a mystery or complicated situation
gradually fall apart or fail to stay organized
examples: She unraveled the old sweater to reuse the yarn
The rope unraveled after years of use
Detectives unraveled the complex conspiracy over several months
Scientists unraveled the genetic code through careful research
Their relationship unraveled after months of arguing constantly
The peace agreement unraveled within weeks of signing

definitions: remove someone from an official position of power or authority
cause someone to fall from their seat, especially from a horse
examples: Voters unseated the incumbent mayor in yesterday's election
The scandal unseated several board members last month
The sudden jump unseated the rider from her horse
The rough terrain nearly unseated him from the bicycle

definitions: remove a veil or covering from something, especially ceremonially
show or announce something publicly for the first time
examples: The artist unveiled the statue at the ceremony
She unveiled her face after the wedding ceremony
The company unveiled its new product line yesterday
The government unveiled plans for healthcare reform today

definitions: undo or become undone after being wound or twisted
relax after a period of work, stress or tension
examples: She unwound the cable from the large spool
The rope unwound as the boat drifted away
I like to unwind with music after work
They unwound at the spa during their vacation

definitions: make something more modern or current by adding new information or features
give someone the latest information about a situation or development
examples: Please update your software to the latest version
They updated the database with recent customer information
Can you update me on the project's progress?
The manager updated staff on policy changes yesterday

definitions: improve something to a higher standard or more advanced version
raise someone to a higher rank, level or position
examples: We upgraded our computer systems last month significantly
Airlines sometimes upgrade passengers to first class free
The military upgraded him to sergeant yesterday officially
The company upgraded her position to senior manager

definitions: maintain, support or defend a principle, law or decision against opposition
confirm or support a previous legal decision on appeal
examples: We must uphold democratic values in our society
The organization upholds high ethical standards consistently
The appeals court upheld the original verdict yesterday
Judges upheld the constitutional right to free speech

definitions: raise something to a higher position or level physically
make someone feel happier or more hopeful emotionally or spiritually
examples: Geological forces uplifted the mountain range over millennia
The crane uplifted heavy beams to the roof
Her encouraging words uplifted my spirits considerably yesterday
Music uplifts the soul during difficult times

definitions: transfer data or files from a local computer to a remote system or internet server
examples: Please upload your assignment to the course website
She uploads videos to her channel every week
The system uploads backup files automatically every night
I uploaded the photos to cloud storage yesterday

definitions: pull a plant, tree or shrub out of the ground including its roots
force someone to leave their home or familiar environment
examples: The storm uprooted several large oak trees yesterday
Gardeners uprooted weeds from the flower beds carefully
War uprooted thousands of families from their homes
The job transfer uprooted them from their community
